# Memory Interchange Format (MIF) - Open Standard for Portable AI Memory

- [Home](https://mif-spec.dev/)

- [File Format](https://mif-spec.dev/specification/file-format/)

- [JSON-LD Format](https://mif-spec.dev/specification/json-ld-format/)

- [Relationship Types](https://mif-spec.dev/specification/relationship-types/)
- [Temporal Model](https://mif-spec.dev/specification/temporal-model/)

- [Schema Reference](https://mif-spec.dev/guides/schema-reference/)

- [Migration Guide](https://mif-spec.dev/guides/migration/)
- [Architecture Decisions](https://mif-spec.dev/design/decisions/)
- [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/zircote/MIF)

## Overview

MIF (Memory Interchange Format) is an open standard for portable AI
memory representation. It defines a vendor-neutral data model with dual
representations: human-readable Markdown files (.memory.md) and
machine-processable JSON-LD documents (.memory.json).

The AI memory ecosystem is fragmented. Mem0, Zep, Letta, LangMem,
Subcog, and others each use proprietary schemas with no
interoperability. MIF addresses this by defining a common data model
that any provider can adopt.

## Key Concepts

- Dual format: .memory.md (Markdown + YAML frontmatter) and .memory.json (JSON-LD)
- Three memory types: semantic (facts), episodic (events), procedural (how-to)
- Bi-temporal model: event time (when it happened) and recording time (when stored)
- Memory decay: confidence degrades over time (exponential, step, linear models)
- Entity types: Person, Organization, Technology, Concept, File
- Nine relationship types: relates_to, derived_from, supersedes, contradicts, supports, blocks, enables, part_of, instance_of
- W3C PROV-based provenance tracking
- Hierarchical namespaces with reserved cognitive prefixes (_semantic, _episodic, _procedural)
- Three conformance levels for progressive adoption
- Obsidian-compatible Markdown files (valid vault notes)
- JSON-LD with semantic web and linked data compatibility

## Specification Version

Current draft: 0.1.0. Uses RFC 2119 conventions (MUST, SHOULD, MAY).
